keyTakeAways: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army due to corruption charges, marking one of the most senior purges in the military since the Cultural Revolution.

He Weidong, China’s number two general and former vice-chair of the Central Military Commission, is the first sitting general on the Central Military Commission to be expelled since 1966-1976, signaling a significant shift in military leadership and anti-corruption efforts.
The expulsions occur just before the Central Committee’s Fourth Plenum, suggesting a strategic timing for Xi Jinping to appoint new officials and restructure key military and political institutions.

He Weidong has close ties to President Xi Jinping, including overlapping service in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces in the late 1990s, and played a key role in planning military drills around Taiwan after Nancy Pelosi’s 2022 visit.
Miao Hua, the former top political officer of the navy, was previously under investigation and removed from the Central Military Commission in June 2024, and now joins He Weidong in being expelled.

The purge involves seven senior military officials, including former political commissars and commanders, many of whom had been absent from public view for months, indicating a broad anti-corruption sweep.
The Pentagon has noted He Weidong’s role in planning live-fire drills around Taiwan, underscoring the strategic importance of these purges in China’s military and foreign policy context.
The expulsions are seen as part of President Xi Jinping’s broader 'cleaning house' effort to consolidate power and remove perceived corruption, especially within elite military and political circles.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army due to corruption charges, marking one of the most senior military purges since the Cultural Revolution. He Weidong, a close associate of President Xi Jinping with deep ties to Taiwan-related military strategy, was promoted directly to vice-chair of the Central Military Commission in 2022 and played a key role in planning live-fire drills around Taiwan after U.S. Speaker Nancy Pelosi visited Taipei in 2022. Miao Hua, the former top political officer of the navy, was previously under investigation and removed in June 2024. The expulsions are part of a broader anti-corruption campaign initiated in 2023, aimed at eliminating corruption and consolidating power. The actions are timed just before the Central Committee’s Fourth Plenum, where new leadership appointments are expected to be formalized, signaling a strategic political restructuring under President Xi Jinping’s leadership.
title: China expels two top generals from Communist Party in anti-corruption crackdown
